org.chronos.chronodb.internal.api

Interface TemporalKeyValueStore

  • All Superinterfaces:
    Lockable, TransactionSource
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractTemporalKeyValueStore, ChunkDbTkvs, InMemoryTKVS, JdbcTkvs, MapDBTkvs, TemporalKeyValueStoreBase, TuplTkvs

    public interface TemporalKeyValueStore
extends TransactionSource, Lockable
    A TemporalKeyValueStore (or TKVS) is a collection of named keyspaces, which in turn contain temporal key-value pairs.

    By default, each non-empty keyspace is associated with a TemporalDataMatrix which performs the actual operations. This class serves as a manager object that forwards the incoming requests to the correct matrix, based upon the keyspace name.

    This class also manages the metadata of a TKVS, in particular the name of the branch to which this TKVS corresponds, the now timestamp, and the index manager used by this TKVS.

    • Nested Class Summary

      • Nested classes/interfaces inherited from interface org.chronos.chronodb.internal.api.Lockable

      • Methods inherited from interface org.chronos.chronodb.api.TransactionSource

    • Method Detail

      • performStartupRecoveryIfRequired

        void performStartupRecoveryIfRequired()
        This method performs recovery operations on this store in case that it was not properly shut down last time.

        If the last shutdown was a regular shutdown, this method will only perform some quick checks and then return. If the last shutdown occurred unexpectedly (e.g. during a commit), a recovery operation will be executed.

      • getOwningDB

        ChronoDBInternal getOwningDB()
        Returns the ChronoDB instance which owns this store.
        Returns:
        The owning database. Never null.

      • getNow

        long getNow()
        Returns the now timestamp.

        The point in time we refer to as now is defined as the last timestamp where a successful commit on this store (in any keyspace) has taken place. Therefore, now is always less than (or equal to) System.currentTimeMillis(). It is a logical point in time which does not necessarily correspond to the current wall clock time.

        In general, transactions are not allowed to be opened after the now timestamp in order to prevent temporal anomalies.

        Returns:
        The now timestamp, i.e. the timestamp of the last successful commit on this store. Never negative.

      • getKeyspaces

        java.util.Set<java.lang.String> getKeyspaces(ChronoDBTransaction tx)
        Returns the set of known keyspace names which are contained in this store.

        The returned set represents the known keyspaces at the given point in time. The set itself is immutable. Calling this operation on different timestamps will produce different sets.

        Parameters:
        tx - The transaction to operate on. Must not be null.
        Returns:
        An immutable set, containing the names of all keyspaces contained in this store.

      • getKeyspaces

        java.util.Set<java.lang.String> getKeyspaces(long timestamp)
        Returns the set of known keyspace names which are contained in this store at the given point in time.

        The returned set represents the known keyspaces at the given point in time. The set itself is immutable. Calling this operation on different timestamps will produce different sets.

        Parameters:
        timestamp - The timestamp to operate on. Must not be negative.
        Returns:
        An immutable set, containing the names of all keyspaces contained in this store.

      • txInternal

        ChronoDBTransaction txInternal(java.lang.String branchName,
                               long timestamp)
        Opens a transaction for internal use.

        This transaction has significantly fewer preconditions and safety checks for the sake of greater flexibility.

        Parameters:
        branchName - The branch to operate on. Must not be null, must refer to an existing branch.
        timestamp - The timestamp to operate on. Must not be negative.
        Returns:
        The new internal transaction. Never null.

      • performCommit

        void performCommit(ChronoDBTransaction tx,
                   java.lang.Object commitMetadata)
        Performs the actual commit operation for the given transaction on this store.

        During this process, the change set (see: ChronoDBTransaction.getChangeSet()) will be written to the actual backing data store, abiding the ACID rules.

        Parameters:
        tx - The transaction to commit. Must not be null.
        commitMetadata - The metadata object to store alongside the commit. May be null. Will be serialized using the SerializationManager associated with this ChronoDB instance.

      • performCommitIncremental

        long performCommitIncremental(ChronoDBTransaction tx)
                       throws ChronoDBCommitException
        Performs an incremental commit, using the given transaction.

        For more details on the incremental commit process, please see ChronoDBTransaction.commitIncremental().

        Parameters:
        tx - The transaction to perform the incremental commit for. Must not be null.
        Returns:
        The new timestamp for the given transaction.
        Throws:
        ChronoDBCommitException - Thrown if the incremental commit fails. If this exception is thrown, any changes made by the incremental commit process will have been rolled back.

      • performIncrementalRollback

        void performIncrementalRollback(ChronoDBTransaction tx)
        Performs a rollback on an inremental commit process started by the given transaction.

        This operation will cancel the incremental commit process and roll back the data store to the state it has been in before the incremental commit started.

        Parameters:
        tx - The transaction that started the incremental commit to roll back. Must not be null.

      • performGet

        java.lang.Object performGet(ChronoDBTransaction tx,
                            QualifiedKey key)
        Performs an actual get operation on this key-value store, in the given transaction.

        A get operation finds the key-value entry E for a given QualifiedKey K where:

        • The keyspace and key in K are equal to the ones in E
        • The timestamp of E is the largest timestamps among all entries that match the other condition, and is less than or equal to the timestamp of the transaction

        ... in other words, this method finds the result of the latest commit operation on the given key, up to (and including) the timestamp which is specified by ChronoDBTransaction.getTimestamp().

        Parameters:
        tx - The transaction in which this operation takes place. Must not be null.
        key - The qualified key to look up in the store. Must not be null.
        Returns:
        The value for the key in this store at the timestamp specified by the transaction. May be null to indicate that either this key was never written, was not yet written at the given time, or has been removed (and not been re-added) before the given time.

      • performRangedGet

        GetResult<java.lang.Object> performRangedGet(ChronoDBTransaction tx,
                                             QualifiedKey key)
        This operation is equivalent to performGet(ChronoDBTransaction, QualifiedKey), but produces additional result data.

        A regular get operation only retrieves the value which was valid in the store at the given point in time. This method will also retrieve a Period indicating from which timestamp to which other timestamp the returned value is valid.

        The result object of this method is essentially just a wrapper for the actual get result, and a validity period.

        Important note: The upper bound of the validity period may exceed the transaction timestamp! It reflects the actual temporal validity range of the key-value pair. This implies a number of special cases:

        • If a key-value pair is the latest entry for a given key (i.e. it has not yet been overridden by any other commit), the value of the period's upper bound will be Long.MAX_VALUE to represent infinity.
        • If there is no entry for a given key, the returned period will be the "eternal" period (i.e. ranging from zero to Long.MAX_VALUE), and the result value will be null.
        • If all entries for a given key are inserted after the requested timestamp, the returned period will start at zero and end at the timestamp where the first key-value pair for the requested key was inserted. The result value will be null in this case.
        • If the last operation that occurred on the key before the requested timestamp was a remove operation, the result value will be null. The period will start at the timestamp where the remove operation occurred. If the key was written again at a later point in time, the period will be terminated at the timestamp of that commit, otherwise the upper bound of the period will be Long.MAX_VALUE.
        Parameters:
        tx - The transaction on which this operation occurs. Must not be null.
        key - The qualified key to search for. Must not be null.
        Returns:
        A GetResult object, containing the actual result value and a temporal validity range as described above. Never null.

      • performKeySet

        java.util.Set<java.lang.String> performKeySet(ChronoDBTransaction tx,
                                              java.lang.String keyspaceName)
        Retrieves the set of keys contained in this store in the given keyspace at the given point in time.

        Please keep in mind that the key set can not only grow (as new keys are being added), but can also shrink when keys are removed. The key set only reflects the keys which have valid (non-null) values at the given point in time.

        Parameters:
        tx - The transaction on which this operation occurs. Must not be null.
        keyspaceName - The name of the keyspace to retrieve the key set for. Must not be null.
        Returns:
        The key set of the given keyspace, at the point in time determined by the given transaction. May be empty, but never null. If the given keyspace is unknown (i.e. does not exist yet), the empty set will be returned.

      • performHistory

        java.util.Iterator<java.lang.Long> performHistory(ChronoDBTransaction tx,
                                                  QualifiedKey key)
        Returns the history of the given key in this store, up to and including the timestamp of the given transaction.

        The history is represented by a number of timestamps. At each of these timestamps, a successful commit operation has modified the value for the given key (and possibly also other key-value pairs).

        The result of this operation is an iterator which iterates over the change timestamps in descending order (i.e. latest changes first). Only commits which have happened before the given transaction (i.e. have timestamps less than or equal to the given transaction timestamp) will be considered as candidates. The iterator may be empty if there are no entries in the history of the given key up to the timestamp of the given transaction (i.e. the key is unknown up to and including the timestamp of the given transaction).

        Parameters:
        tx - The transaction on which this operation occurs. Must not be null.
        key - The key to retrieve the history (change timestamps) for. Must not be null.
        Returns:
        An iterator over all change timestamps (descending order; latest changes first) up to (and including) the timestamp of the given transaction, as specified above. May be empty, but never null.

      • performGetModificationsInKeyspaceBetween

        java.util.Iterator<TemporalKey> performGetModificationsInKeyspaceBetween(ChronoDBTransaction tx,
                                                                         java.lang.String keyspace,
                                                                         long timestampLowerBound,
                                                                         long timestampUpperBound)
        Returns an iterator over the modified keys in the given timestamp range.

        Please note that timestampLowerBound and timestampUpperBound must not be larger than the timestamp of the transaction, i.e. you can only look for timestamp ranges in the past with this method.

        Parameters:
        tx - The transaction to work with. Must not be null.
        keyspace - The keyspace to look for changes in. Must not be null. For non-existing keyspaces, the resulting iterator will be empty.
        timestampLowerBound - The lower bound on the time range to look for. Must not be negative. Must be less than or equal to timestampUpperBound. Must be less than or equal to the timestamp of this transaction.
        timestampUpperBound - The upper bound on the time range to look for. Must not be negative. Must be greater than or equal to timestampLowerBound. Must be less than or equal to the timestamp of this transaction.
        Returns:
        An iterator containing the TemporalKeys that reflect the modifications. May be empty, but never null.

      • performGetCommitMetadata

        java.lang.Object performGetCommitMetadata(ChronoDBTransaction tx,
                                          long commitTimestamp)
        Returns the metadata object stored alongside the commit at the given timestamp.

        It is important that the given timestamp matches the commit timestamp exactly.

        Parameters:
        tx - The transaction to work with. Must not be null.
        commitTimestamp - The commit timestamp to get the metadata object for. Must match the commit timestamp exactly. Must not be negative. Must be less than or equal to the timestamp of this transaction (i.e. must be in the past).
        Returns:
        The object stored alongside that commit. Will be null for all timestamps that are not associated with a commit. May also be null in cases where no metadata object was given for the commit by the user.

      • performGetCommitTimestampsBetween

        java.util.Iterator<java.lang.Long> performGetCommitTimestampsBetween(ChronoDBTransaction tx,
                                                                     long from,
                                                                     long to,
                                                                     Order order)
        Returns an iterator over all timestamps where commits have occurred, bounded between from and to.

        If the from value is greater than the to value, this method always returns an empty iterator.

        Parameters:
        tx - The transaction to work on. Must not be null.
        from - The lower bound of the time range to look for commits in (inclusive). Must not be negative. Must be less than or equal to the timestamp of this transaction.
        to - The upper bound of the time range to look for commits in (inclusive). Must not be negative. Must be less than or equal to the timestamp of this transaction.
        order - The order of the returned timestamps. Must not be null.
        Returns:
        The iterator over the commit timestamps in the given time range. May be empty, but never null.

      • performGetCommitMetadataBetween

        java.util.Iterator<java.util.Map.Entry<java.lang.Long,java.lang.Object>> performGetCommitMetadataBetween(ChronoDBTransaction tx,
                                                                                                         long from,
                                                                                                         long to,
                                                                                                         Order order)
        Returns an iterator over the entries of commit timestamp and associated metadata, bounded between from and to.

        If the from value is greater than the to value, this method always returns an empty iterator.

        Please keep in mind that some commits may not have any metadata attached. In this case, the value component of the Map.Entry will be set to null.

        Parameters:
        tx - The transaction to work on. Must not be null.
        from - The lower bound of the time range to look for commits in (inclusive). Must not be negative. Must be less than or equal to the timestamp of this transaction.
        to - The upper bound of the time range to look for commits in (inclusive). Must not be negative. Must be less than or equal to the timestamp of this transaction.
        order - The order of the returned commits. Must not be null.
        Returns:
        An iterator over the commits in the given time range. The contained entries have the timestamp as the key component and the associated metadata as their value component (which may be null). May be empty, but never null.

      • performGetCommitTimestampsPaged

        java.util.Iterator<java.lang.Long> performGetCommitTimestampsPaged(ChronoDBTransaction tx,
                                                                   long minTimestamp,
                                                                   long maxTimestamp,
                                                                   int pageSize,
                                                                   int pageIndex,
                                                                   Order order)
        Returns an iterator over commit timestamps in a paged fashion.

        For example, calling getCommitTimestampsPaged(10000, 100, 0, Order.DESCENDING) will give the latest 100 commit timestamps that have occurred before timestamp 10000. Calling getCommitTimestampsPaged(123456, 200, 2, Order.DESCENDING will return 200 commit timestamps, skipping the 400 latest commit timestamps, which are smaller than 123456.

        Parameters:
        tx - The transaction to use. Must not be null.
        minTimestamp - The minimum timestamp to consider (inclusive). All lower timestamps will be excluded from the pagination. Must be less than or equal to the timestamp of this transaction.
        maxTimestamp - The highest timestamp to consider (inclusive). All higher timestamps will be excluded from the pagination. Must be less than or equal to the timestamp of this transaction.
        pageSize - The size of the page, i.e. the maximum number of elements allowed to be contained in the resulting iterator. Must be greater than zero.
        pageIndex - The index of the page to retrieve. Must not be negative.
        order - The desired ordering for the commit timestamps
        Returns:
        An iterator that contains the commit timestamps for the requested page. Never null, may be empty. If the requested page does not exist, this iterator will always be empty.

      • performGetCommitMetadataPaged

        java.util.Iterator<java.util.Map.Entry<java.lang.Long,java.lang.Object>> performGetCommitMetadataPaged(ChronoDBTransaction tx,
                                                                                                       long minTimestamp,
                                                                                                       long maxTimestamp,
                                                                                                       int pageSize,
                                                                                                       int pageIndex,
                                                                                                       Order order)
        Returns an iterator over commit timestamps and associated metadata in a paged fashion.

        For example, calling getCommitTimestampsPaged(10000, 100, 0, Order.DESCENDING) will give the latest 100 commit timestamps that have occurred before timestamp 10000. Calling getCommitTimestampsPaged(123456, 200, 2, Order.DESCENDING will return 200 commit timestamps, skipping the 400 latest commit timestamps, which are smaller than 123456.

        The Entries returned by the iterator always have the commit timestamp as their first component and the metadata associated with this commit as their second component. The second component can be null if the commit was executed without providing metadata.

        Parameters:
        tx - The transaction to work on. Must not be null.
        minTimestamp - The minimum timestamp to consider (inclusive). All lower timestamps will be excluded from the pagination. Must be less than or equal to the timestamp of this transaction.
        maxTimestamp - The highest timestamp to consider. All higher timestamps will be excluded from the pagination. Must be less than or equal to the timestamp of this transaction.
        pageSize - The size of the page, i.e. the maximum number of elements allowed to be contained in the resulting iterator. Must be greater than zero.
        pageIndex - The index of the page to retrieve. Must not be negative.
        order - The desired ordering for the commit timestamps
        Returns:
        An iterator that contains the commits for the requested page. Never null, may be empty. If the requested page does not exist, this iterator will always be empty.

      • performGetCommitMetadataAround

        java.util.List<java.util.Map.Entry<java.lang.Long,java.lang.Object>> performGetCommitMetadataAround(long timestamp,
                                                                                                    int count)
        Returns pairs of commit timestamp and commit metadata which are "around" the given timestamp on the time axis.

        By default, this method will attempt to return the closest count/2 commits before and after the given timestamp. However, if there are not enough elements on either side, the other side will have more entries in the result list (e.g. if the request count is 10 and there are only two commits before the request timestamp, the list of commits after the request timestamp will have 8 entries instead of 5 to create a list of total length 10). In other words, the result list will always have as many entries as the request count, except when there are not as many commits on the store yet.

        Parameters:
        timestamp - The request timestamp around which the commits should be centered. Must not be negative.
        count - How many commits to retrieve around the request timestamp. By default, the closest count/2 commits will be taken on both sides of the request timestamp. Must not be negative.
        Returns:
        A list of pairs. The keys are commit timsetamps, the corresponding values are the commit metadata objects (which may be null). The list itself will never be null, but may be empty (if there are no commits to report). The list is sorted in descending order by timestamp.

      • performGetCommitMetadataBefore

        java.util.List<java.util.Map.Entry<java.lang.Long,java.lang.Object>> performGetCommitMetadataBefore(long timestamp,
                                                                                                    int count)
        Returns pairs of commit timestamp and commit metadata which are strictly before the given timestamp on the time axis.

        For example, calling performGetCommitMetadataBefore(long, int) with a timestamp and a count of 10, this method will return the latest 10 commits (strictly) before the given request timestamp.

        Parameters:
        timestamp - The timestamp to investigate. Must not be negative.
        count - How many commits to retrieve before the given request timestamp. Must not be negative.
        Returns:
        A list of pairs. The keys are commit timsetamps, the corresponding values are the commit metadata objects (which may be null). The list itself will never be null, but may be empty (if there are no commits to report). The list is sorted in descending order by timestamp.

      • performGetCommitMetadataAfter

        java.util.List<java.util.Map.Entry<java.lang.Long,java.lang.Object>> performGetCommitMetadataAfter(long timestamp,
                                                                                                   int count)
        Returns pairs of commit timestamp and commit metadata which are strictly after the given timestamp on the time axis.

        For example, calling performGetCommitMetadataAfter(long, int) with a timestamp and a count of 10, this method will return the oldest 10 commits (strictly) after the given request timestamp.

        Parameters:
        timestamp - The timestamp to investigate. Must not be negative.
        count - How many commits to retrieve after the given request timestamp. Must not be negative.
        Returns:
        A list of pairs. The keys are commit timsetamps, the corresponding values are the commit metadata objects (which may be null). The list itself will never be null, but may be empty (if there are no commits to report). The list is sorted in descending order by timestamp.

      • performGetCommitTimestampsAround

        java.util.List<java.lang.Long> performGetCommitTimestampsAround(long timestamp,
                                                                int count)
        Returns a list of commit timestamp which are "around" the given timestamp on the time axis.

        By default, this method will attempt to return the closest count/2 commits before and after the given timestamp. However, if there are not enough elements on either side, the other side will have more entries in the result list (e.g. if the request count is 10 and there are only two commits before the request timestamp, the list of commits after the request timestamp will have 8 entries instead of 5 to create a list of total length 10). In other words, the result list will always have as many entries as the request count, except when there are not as many commits on the store yet.

        Parameters:
        timestamp - The request timestamp around which the commits should be centered. Must not be negative.
        count - How many commits to retrieve around the request timestamp. By default, the closest count/2 commits will be taken on both sides of the request timestamp. Must not be negative.
        Returns:
        A list of timestamps. Never be null, but may be empty (if there are no commits to report). The list is sorted in descending order.

      • performGetCommitTimestampsBefore

        java.util.List<java.lang.Long> performGetCommitTimestampsBefore(long timestamp,
                                                                int count)
        Returns a list of commit timestamps which are strictly before the given timestamp on the time axis.

        For example, calling performGetCommitTimestampsBefore(long, int) with a timestamp and a count of 10, this method will return the latest 10 commits (strictly) before the given request timestamp.

        Parameters:
        timestamp - The timestamp to investigate. Must not be negative.
        count - How many commits to retrieve before the given request timestamp. Must not be negative.
        Returns:
        A list of timestamps. Never be null, but may be empty (if there are no commits to report). The list is sorted in descending order.

      • performGetCommitTimestampsAfter

        java.util.List<java.lang.Long> performGetCommitTimestampsAfter(long timestamp,
                                                               int count)
        Returns a list of commit timestamps which are strictly after the given timestamp on the time axis.

        For example, calling performGetCommitTimestampsAfter(long, int) with a timestamp and a count of 10, this method will return the oldest 10 commits (strictly) after the given request timestamp.

        Parameters:
        timestamp - The timestamp to investigate. Must not be negative.
        count - How many commits to retrieve after the given request timestamp. Must not be negative.
        Returns:
        A list of timestamps. Never be null, but may be empty (if there are no commits to report). The list is sorted in descending order.

      • performCountCommitTimestampsBetween

        int performCountCommitTimestampsBetween(ChronoDBTransaction tx,
                                        long from,
                                        long to)
        Counts the number of commit timestamps between from (inclusive) and to (inclusive).

        If from is greater than to, this method will always return zero.

        Parameters:
        tx - The transaction to work on. Must not be null.
        from - The minimum timestamp to include in the search (inclusive). Must not be negative. Must be less than or equal to the timestamp of this transaction.
        to - The maximum timestamp to include in the search (inclusive). Must not be negative. Must be less than or equal to the timestamp of this transaction.
        Returns:
        The number of commits that have occurred in the specified time range. May be zero, but never negative.

      • performCountCommitTimestamps

        int performCountCommitTimestamps(ChronoDBTransaction tx)
        Counts the total number of commit timestamps in the store.
        Parameters:
        tx - The transaction to work on. Must not be null.
        Returns:
        The total number of commits in the store.

      • lockNonExclusive

        Lockable.LockHolder lockNonExclusive()
        Declares that a thread is about to perform a non-exclusive task that can run in parallel with other non-exclusive locking tasks.

        This method ensures that non-exclusive operations are properly blocked when an exclusive operation is taking place.

        This method also acquires the non-exclusive lock on the whole database!

        This method must be used together with the try-with-resources pattern. See Lockable.lockNonExclusive() for an example.

        Specified by:
        lockNonExclusive in interface Lockable
        Returns:
        The object representing the lock ownership. Never null. Will be closed automatically by the try-with-resources statement.

      • lockExclusive

        Lockable.LockHolder lockExclusive()
        Declares that a thread is about to perform an exclusive task that can't run in parallel with other locking tasks.

        This method acquires the exclusive lock on the entire database!

        This method must be used together with the try-with-resources pattern. See Lockable.lockExclusive() for an example.

        Specified by:
        lockExclusive in interface Lockable
        Returns:
        The object representing the lock ownership. Never null. Will be closed automatically by the try-with-resources statement.

      • lockBranchExclusive

        Lockable.LockHolder lockBranchExclusive()
        Declares that a thread is about to perform a non-exclusive task that can run in parallel with other non-exclusive locking tasks on this branch.

        This method also acquires the non-exclusive lock on the whole database!

        This method must be used together with the try-with-resources pattern. See Lockable.lockNonExclusive() for an example.

        Returns:
        The object representing the lock ownership. Never null. Will be closed automatically by the try-with-resources statement.

      • allEntriesIterator

        CloseableIterator<ChronoDBEntry> allEntriesIterator(long maxTimestamp)
        Returns an iterator over all entries in this data store which have timestamps less than or equal to the given timestamp.

        This method is intended primarily for operations that perform backup work on the database. It is strongly discouraged to perform any kind of filtering or analysis on the returned iterator (for performance reasons); use one of the other retrieval methods provided by this class instead.

        /!\ WARNING /!\
        This method will return only entries from this branch! Entries from the origin branch (if any) will not be included in the returned iterator!

        /!\ WARNING /!\
        The resulting iterator must be closed by the caller!

        Parameters:
        maxTimestamp - The maximum timestamp to consider. Only entries with timestamps less than or equal to this value will be returned. Must not be negative.
        Returns:
        An iterator over all entries with timestamps less than or equal to the given timestamp. May be empty, but never null. Must be closed by the caller.

      • insertEntries

        void insertEntries(java.util.Set<ChronoDBEntry> entries)
        Directly inserts the given entries into this store, without performing any temporal consistency checks.

        This method is intended to be used only for loading a previously stored backup, and is strongly discouraged for regular use. Please use transactions and commits instead to ensure temporal consistency.

        Parameters:
        entries - The set of entries to insert. Must not be null. If the set is empty, this method is effectively a no-op.
